abstract.para: The openSUSE Build Service is an open and complete distribution development platform. It supplies the infrastructure for the development of the openSUSE distribution. Furthermore it provides software developers with a tool to compile, release and publish their software for different Linux distributions and makes it available to the broad user audience. The openSUSE Build Service also provide means to create custom Linux distributions for various hardware architectures.

sect1.title: Features
sect1.para: Although the Build Service is primarily a platform for developers, it also offers functionality for Linux users and even for distributors. The Build Service is currently work in progress. Future versions will, for instance, have a trust management for users and projects. It is also planned to offer the build of flavors of distributions, such as openSUSE for XEN, Live DVDs, and others. More information on planned features are availabe at and .

sect2.title: Features for Developers
sect2.para: A developer who wants to make his software available for as much people as possible, faces three major problems:

listitem.para: The software should run on most distributions.
The software should run on different versions of distributions.
The software should run on most hardware platforms.

sect2.para: It is almost impossible to meet these challenges for a regular developer. He not only would have to have all target distributions and versions installed, he would also have to have access all hardware platforms the software should be available for.

The Build Service solves these issues. Apart from openSUSE, it supports other popular Linux distributions (like Fedora, Debian, Ubuntu, and others) as well as several hardware platforms (i386, x86-64, and PPC [planned]).

Another major issue are package dependencies. Most software depends on other software packages (such as libraries, for instance). The Build Service automatically resolves these dependencies. Whatsmore, it even triggers an automatic package rebuild once a depending package has been updated. Therefore it is no longer necessary to keep track of package changes on all target distributions.

When maintaining software depending on other projects such as KDE or GNOME, for instance, it is possible to link the package to these projects. This ensures that a rebuild is triggered when the project it is linked to is also rebuilded.
Each software project on the Build Service is hosted in a workspace called project. Each project can have sub-projects and different projects can be linked to each other.

sect2.title: Features for Users
sect2.para: Each project that is hosted on the Build Service is available for download and installation via repositories of various formats (apt, rpm-md [Yum], SUSE legacy). Using these repositories users can easily get the latest version of their favorite software. Since dependencies are automatically resolved, it is even possible to always update to the latest versions of large projects such as KDE or GNOME.

Since the Build Service not only hosts current distributions, it also provides updates for older versions. Theoretically it is also possible to provide security updates for distributions no longer maintained.

The (planned) trust management where users rate projects and project owners, helps to find out about the popularity of a certain project. If a user likes a certain project, he can promote it by voting for it.

sect2.title: Features for Distributors
sect2.para: The Build Service is able to create complete distributions or modified images easily to be used in different ways. A first version of KIWI to create images for booting via network or to be used as Xen or VMware image has been released. See for more information.
